title: Connection retry detection
description:
Purpose:
- Detect and highlight reconnection patterns (same remote, repeated connect/close cycles)
- Surface rate limiting, network issues, or bugs in AI clients

User impact:
- See warning: '‚ö† Retry pattern: 5 connections to api.anthropic.com:443 in 30s'
- Identify problematic connection behavior without manual analysis
- Correlate retries with provider responses

Features:
- Track connection events per (remote_ip, remote_port, pid)
- Configurable threshold: --retry-threshold <N> (default 3)
- Configurable window: --retry-window-ms <N> (default 60000)
- Output retry warnings inline with events
- Store retry_count in SQLite for analysis

Implementation:
- HashMap<(IpAddr, u16, u32), Vec<Instant>> for recent connections
- On close event: check if count in window exceeds threshold
- Prune old entries on check (sliding window)

Testing:
- Unit tests for retry detection logic
- E2E script that simulates rapid reconnects
- Verify warnings appear and SQLite has retry counts

title: Design alert system architecture
description:
Deliverables:

- Decision on pattern matching library (regex vs glob vs both)
- Define alert event structure for SQLite storage
- Define alert output format (stderr, prefix, colors)
- Decide on alert state tracking (cooldown to avoid spam)

Design questions to answer:
1. Should alerts be per-connection or per-threshold-breach?
2. How to handle alert cooldown (same alert within N seconds)?
3. Should we track 'alert acknowledged' state?
4. How do alerts interact with --json output mode?

Output:
- Design doc in docs/alert-design.md
- Updated schema proposal for events table
design:
Design decisions (pre-answered to speed implementation):
1. Alerts should be per-connection (each matching event triggers alert, subject to cooldown)
2. Cooldown: HashMap<AlertType, Instant> - skip alert if same type within cooldown_ms
3. No 'acknowledged' state for v1 - keep it simple, user handles alerts
4. JSON mode: alerts as JSON objects on stderr with alert:true field, same structure as events

Pattern matching approach:
- Use glob for simple wildcards (most common case)
- Allow regex with r: prefix for power users (e.g., 'r:.*evil.*')
- Default to glob if no prefix

title: Design export format and CLI
description:
Deliverables:
- CLI design document:
  rano export [OPTIONS]
  --format csv|jsonl (required)
  --sqlite <path> (default: observer.sqlite)
  --since <timestamp|relative> (e.g., 24h, 7d, 2026-01-20)
  --until <timestamp|relative>
  --run-id <id>
  --provider <name> (repeatable)
  --domain <pattern> (repeatable)
  --fields <list> (optional: override default field list)
  --no-header (CSV only: skip header row)

- Define field order and names:
  ts, run_id, event, provider, pid, comm, cmdline, proto, local_ip, local_port, remote_ip, remote_port, domain, duration_ms

- CSV format spec:
  - RFC 4180 compliant
  - Fields with commas/quotes/newlines properly escaped
  - UTF-8 encoding
  - CRLF line endings (for Excel compatibility)

- JSONL format spec:
  - One JSON object per line
  - UTF-8 encoding
  - LF line endings
  - Same fields as CSV

- Output: docs/export-design.md
design:
Implementation notes:
- CSV escaping: double quotes to escape quotes, wrap fields containing comma/quote/newline
- No external CSV crate needed - simple escaping logic
- Streaming: use SQLite row iteration with step(), don't collect()
- Memory: flush stdout every 1000 rows
- Empty result: CSV outputs header only, JSONL outputs nothing
- Progress: no progress bar (would interfere with piping)
- Errors: fail fast on invalid filter, print to stderr

Query template:
SELECT ts, run_id, event, provider, pid, comm, cmdline, proto,
       local_ip, local_port, remote_ip, remote_port, domain, duration_ms
FROM events
WHERE 1=1
  [AND ts >= :since]
  [AND ts < :until]
  [AND run_id = :run_id]
  [AND provider IN (:providers)]
  [AND domain LIKE :domain_pattern]
ORDER BY ts ASC

title: Implement ancestry chain reading
description:
Deliverables:
- read_ancestry(pid) -> Vec<(u32, String)>:
  - Walk /proc/{pid}/stat to get PPID
  - Recursively read parent until PPID=0 or PPID=1
  - Return chain from root to current: [(init_pid, init_comm), ..., (pid, comm)]

- AncestryCache struct:
  - cache: HashMap<u32, (Vec<(u32, String)>, Instant)>
  - ttl: Duration (default 30s)
  - get_or_compute(pid) method with staleness check

- Staleness detection:
  - If cached entry exists, verify current comm matches cached comm
  - If mismatch (PID recycled), invalidate and recompute

- format_ancestry(chain) -> String:
  - Output: 'zsh(123) ‚Üí tmux(456) ‚Üí claude(789)'
  - Truncate if >5 levels: '... ‚Üí parent(456) ‚Üí claude(789)'
  - Handle single-level: 'claude(789)'

- Integration:
  - Add ancestry_cache to main state
  - Lookup ancestry when --show-ancestry enabled
  - Pass ancestry to event formatting
design:
Implementation approach:
- Reuse existing read_ppid() from descendant tracking
- Stack-based iteration (not recursion) to avoid stack overflow
- Stop at PPID=0 (kernel) or PPID=1 (init/systemd)
- Reverse to get root‚Üíleaf order

Performance considerations:
- Cache is essential - ancestry changes rarely
- 30s TTL is reasonable (processes don't typically reparent)
- Staleness check: comm is sufficient (PID reuse with same comm is rare)
- Memory: ~100 bytes per cached entry, max ~1000 tracked PIDs = 100KB

Edge cases:
- Process exits during walk: return partial chain with '?' for missing
- Zombie process: use comm from cmdline fallback
- Init containers: stop at container init, not host init

title: Design batching strategy
description:
Deliverables:

- Specify how backpressure events are logged (rate-limited warnings).
design:
Batching strategy proposal

Defaults
- queue_capacity: 10_000 events (bounded sync_channel)
- batch_size: 200 events (transaction per batch)
- flush_interval_ms: 1000 (forces a write even if batch not full)
- max_send_block_ms: 5 (optional brief backpressure before drop)

Writer model
- Single SQLite writer thread owns Connection. Producers send SqlMsg::Event(event) via sync_channel.
- Writer loop drains channel: accumulate Vec<Event> until batch_size reached or flush_interval elapsed, then write in a single transaction with prepared stmt.
- Flush on Shutdown: producer sends SqlMsg::Shutdown; writer drains remaining events, flushes, then exits. Main thread joins writer before finalize_session.

Backpressure + memory cap
- Bounded channel provides memory cap.
- Producer uses try_send (or short timeout via send_timeout) so poller doesn‚Äôt stall. If full after timeout, drop newest event and increment dropped counter.
- Expose dropped count in summary and/or stats (optional).

Backpressure logging
- Rate-limit warning (e.g., once per 10s) to stderr and log file: "warning: sqlite queue full, dropped N events (total M)".
- Reset per-interval counter after logging.

Rationale
- Poll loop stays responsive; DB writes amortized; bounded memory; graceful shutdown flush minimizes loss.

design:
Stats views + CLI flag design

Flags
- --stats-view <provider|domain|port|process> (repeatable).
  - If omitted: default view list = [provider].
  - If provided multiple times: cycle only those views (preserve order).
- --stats-cycle-ms <ms> (default 0/off). When >0 and stats enabled, rotate views at this interval.
- Existing --stats-interval-ms controls refresh cadence; cycle is independent (switch view on next refresh after cycle elapses).

Top-N + formatting
- Reuse --stats-top (default 5) for domain/port/process lists.
- Provider view shows all providers with bars.
- Domain view: top domains by count; include provider aggregate counts in parentheses if available.
- Port view: top remote ports by count; optionally show proto.
- Process view: top comm names by count.

Terminal width / TTY behavior
- If stdout is TTY: compute bar width from --stats-width if set, else from COLUMNS (clamped 20..80).
- If stdout is NOT TTY: suppress live stats by default; only print final summary (current behavior) or emit compact one-line stats per interval if --stats-interval-ms > 0 and --summary-only=false.
- When --json is set: disable live stats output regardless of view/cycle.

Notes
- Views should render as distinct sections with a short header (e.g., "Live Stats [domain]").
- Cycling should be no-op if stats interval is 0 or summary-only is enabled.

title: Test harness + logging standard for E2E
description:
Purpose:
- Ensure every e2e script has consistent, high-signal logging and reproducible behavior.

Deliverables:
- Shared e2e runner (shell or Rust) that standardizes log format:
  - header with timestamp, host, OS, rano version, args
  - inputs/fixtures summary
  - expected outputs
  - actual outputs (truncated with pointers)
  - pass/fail summary
- Standard log location convention (e.g., `logs/e2e/<test-name>-<ts>.log`).
- Helper functions for asserting output (string/regex) with detailed diffs.

Notes:
- Keep runner minimal; do not require elevated privileges.
- All e2e beads must depend on this harness.
